introduction.p: Acceleration is an important characteristic of motion. It connects the motion of an object to the influence of environment on the motion. In this first exposure to this topic, we will focus on motion along x-axis only. In a later chapter we will study acceleration in a more general setting.

Similar to our treatment of velocity, we will define an average acceleration and an instantaneous acceleration. For a motion on the x axis, we will denote instantaneous acceleration by symbol a_x and average acceleration by a_{\text{av},x}.

subsection.title: Average Acceleration
subsection.p:
The average rate of change of velocity during a finite interval can be obtained by dividing the change in velocity by the interval. Let v_{i,x} be the (instantaneous) velocity at instant t_i and v_{f,x} be the (instantaneous) velocity at instant t_f, then average acceleration, a_{\text{av},x} during t_i to t_f, will be
a_{\text{av},x} = \dfrac{v_{f,x} - v_{i,x}}{ t_f - t_i}.
You can see that writing all the subscripts can be too tedious. So, if there is no confusion that we are working along one axis and that we are dealing with average acceleration, we can write this definition much more simply by dropping off all the unnecessary subscripts as follows.
a = \dfrac{v_{f} - v_{i}}{ t_f - t_i}.
However, for the sake of being specific and completeness, in the book I will continue to add all the necessary subscripts, but in your studies, you don't have to bother as long as you are clear about what you are suppressing. By writing \Delta v_x for v_{f,x} - v_{i,x} and \Delta t for t_f - t_i, we often write this as
a_{\text{av},x} = \dfrac{\Delta v_x}{ \Delta t},
Note that for average aceleration, we do not need to know the details of the motion at any instant other than what happened at just the initial and final instants. For instance, for a motion shown in , the average acceleration between A and B will be obtained from v_x at those points and time between them.

sidebyside.p:
Note that v_x(\text{at B}) is negative since the particle is moving towards negative x axis although it is on the positive x-axis.
\amp v_x(A) = 2.0\text{ m/s}, \amp v_x(B) = - 2.0\text{ m/s}, \amp a_{\text{av},x} = \frac{-2.0-2.0}{2.0} = -2.0\text{ m/s}^2.

example.title: Change in Velocity from Average Acceleration

statement.p: A box is moving on x-axis with velocity of +12.0\text{ m/s} and has a constant acceleration of -9.0\text{ m/s}^2. Find its velocity after (a) 1\text{ sec}, (b) 2\text{ s}.

solution.title: a
solution.p:
If the acceleration is constant, then this acceleration is same as average acceleration. From the definition of average acceleration we have the change in velocity to be
\Delta v_x = a_x\, \Delta t.
Therefore in one second
\Delta v_x = -9.0 \times 1 = -9.0\text{ m/s}.
Adding this to the initial velocity gives
v_x(\text{at }t=1\text{ sec}) = v_{ix} + \Delta v_x = 12 - 9 = 3.0\text{ m/s}.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
In 2 sec:
\Delta v_x = -9.0 \times 2 = -18.0\text{ m/s}.
Adding this to the initial velocity gives
v_x(\text{at }t=2\text{ sec}) = v_{ix} + \Delta v_x = 12 - 18 = -6.0\text{ m/s}.
The negative sign here means the object is not moving in the direction of the negative x-axis.

subsection.title: Instantaneous Acceleration
subsection.p:
Often we want acceleration at a particular instant, called instantaneous acceleration, or simply, acceleration.
This is the rate of change of velocity at that instant. Again, here we just look at a one-dimensional motion on the x-axis and defer the more complete treatment to a later chapter.

Consider an arbitrary motion on x-axis. Let v_x\left(\text{at } t\right) be the x-velocity at instant t and v_x\left(\text{at } t+\Delta t\right) at instant (t+\Delta t). Then, x-acceleration a_x AT INSTANT t will be defined by the limiting process of taking the duration \Delta t as close to zero as possible except \Delta t = 0.
a_x = \lim_{\Delta t \rightarrow 0}\dfrac{v_x\left(\text{at } t+\Delta t\right) - v_x\left(\text{at } t\right)}{\Delta t}.
Of course, we also denote this process by a simler notation of the derivative symbol, dv_x/dt, where we think of v_x as a continuous function of t.
a_x = \dfrac{dv_x}{dt}.
Recall that graphically, the derivative of a function is also slope of tangent at that point. Here, we look at the plot of v_x (on the ordinate) versus t (on the abscissa). Then, a_x can be computed by the slope of the tangent to the v_x versus t at the instant of interest.

remark.title: Positive and Negative a_x do not tell direction of motion
remark.p: Recall that positive v_x corresponded to the object moving towards x=+\infty and negative v_x corresponded to moving towards -\infty. But, positive and negative a_x do not have such simple interpretations. Positive a_x means the v_x of the motion is becoming more positive with time and negative a_x means v_x of the motion is becoming more negative with time. Let us look at two important cases.

sidebyside.p: Positive a_x adds positive velocity values to v_x. Thus if an object is initially moving towards positive x-axis, it will speed up and if it was moving towards the negative x-axis, it will slow down. In this later case, if a_x remains the same, the object will eventually turn around and move towards positive x-axis, i.e., v_x eventually becoming positive.

Negative a_x adds negative velocity values to v_x. Thus if an object is initially moving towards negative x-axis, it will speed up and if it was moving towards the positive x-axis, it will slow down. In this later case, if a_x remains the same, the object will eventually turn around and move towards negative x-axis, i.e., v_x eventually becoming negative.

statement.p: In theoretical work you might find that you are given position as a function x(t) . For example, a block attached to a spring oscillates with its position x(t) = (5 \text{ cm}) \cos( 2\pi t), where t is in seconds. If you plot this x versus t , you will notice that the block moves between x = - 5 cm and x = 5 cm, repeating a complete cycle every second.
(a) What is the velocity of this block at (i) t = 0.25 s, (ii) t = 0.5 s, and (iii) t = 0.75 s.
(b) What is the acceleration of this block at (a) t = 0.25 s, (b) t = 0.5 s, and (c) t = 0.75 s.

solution.title: a
solution.p: Taking the derivative of given x(t) and then evaluating the result at the required times should give us the answers.

solution.title: b
solution.p: Taking the derivative of v_x and then evaluating the result at the requires times should give us the answers.

subsection.title: Graphical Definition of Acceleration
subsection.p:
Since the slope of a function is the rate of change of that function, the rate of change of velocity at a particular instant can be obtained from the slope of the tangent of the velocity versus time plot. We can take this as defining acceleration a_x for one-dimensional motion on the x axis.
a_x = \text{ slope of tangent to }v_x\text{ versus }t.
If the plot of v_x versus t is linear, i.e., a straight line as in Fig. , then the tangent line is same as the line of the plot, hence a_x is just the slope of the line.

figure.caption: The slope of v_x versus t plot gives the acceleration a_x . Since the plot is linear, the slope is same for all instants plotted. In (a) a_x = 1.0 \text{ m/s}^2 and in (b) a_x = - 0.75 \text{ m/s}^2.

subsection.p: But, if the plot of v_x versus t is curved as in , then you would draw a tangent line at the instant of interest, and compute the slope of the tangent line to get a_x .

figure.caption: The slope of v_x versus t plot gives the acceleration a_x . Since the plot is not linear, we need to first draw a tangent line at the instant we want the acceleration value. The figure illustrates a_x at t = 4\text{ sec}, where the slope of the tangent line is a_x = (4-(-1))/(5-3) = 2.5\text{ m/s}^2 .

example.title: Using slope of v_x to compute a_x

statement.p: From the v_x versus t plot in , find a_x at the following instants: (a) t = 1\text{ sec}, (b) t = 3\text{ sec} , and (c) t = 3.75\text{ sec} .

solution.title: a
solution.p: (a) The v_x versus t plot through the time when t = 1\text{ sec} is a straight line. Therefore, a_x will simply be slope of this part of the plot. The slope of this line is clearly zero. Therefore, a_x (\text{at }t=1\text{ sec}) = 0.

(b) The v_x versus t plot through the time when t = 3\text{ sec} is a straight line. Therefore, a_x will simply be slope of this part of the plot. The slope of this line is obtained by picking two points on the line between t = 2\text{ sec} and t = 3.5\text{ sec}. We pick points at t = 2\text{ sec} and t = 3\text{ sec} to obtain
a_x = \dfrac{0 - 4\text{ m/s}}{3\text{ s}-2\text{ s}} = -4\text{ m/s}^2.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
The v_x versus t plot through the time when t = 3.75\text{ sec} is a straight line. Therefore, a_x will simply be slope of this part of the plot. The slope of this line is obtained by picking two points on the line between t = 3.5\text{ sec} and t = 4.0\text{ sec}. We pick points at t = 3.5\text{ sec} and t = 4\text{ sec} to obtain
a_x = \dfrac{0 - (-2)\text{ m/s}}{4\text{ s}-3.5\text{ s}} = 4\text{ m/s}^2.

subsection.title: Change in Velocity from Acceleration
subsection.p:
Suppose a motion is along x-axis with velocity v_x at instant t and (v_x+\Delta v_x) at instant t + \Delta t. Here \Delta v_x stands for whatever is the change in velocity during the interval. Then, recall that average acceleration for the finite interval t to t + \Delta t will be
a_{x,av} = \frac{(v_x + \Delta v_x) - v_x}{ (t + \Delta t) - t} = \frac{\Delta v_x}{\Delta t}.
Then, we can immediately get the change in velocity \Delta v_x by multiplying both sides by the interval \Delta t.
\Delta v_x = a_{x,av}\,\Delta t.
How about getting the change in velocity \Delta v_x from instantaneous acceleration a_x given at each instant between t and t + \Delta t? Since a_x is the derivative of the instantaneous velocity taken as a function of time, v_x(t), to get the change in v_x, we will need to integrate a_x, which is itself a function of t. Let us denote t_i for the intitial instant and t_f for the final instant, and v_{x,f}-v_{x,i} for \Delta v_x.
a_x = \frac{dv_x}{dt}\ \ \longleftrightarrow\ \ v_{x,f} - v_{x,i} = \int_{t_i}^{t_f}\, a_x(t)\,dt.
Now, an integral has a nice graphical interpretation - it is the area "under or over" the curve! You have already seen this in the context of velocity/displacement relation.
v_x = \frac{dx}{dt}\ \ \longleftrightarrow\ \ x_f - x_i = \int_{t_i}^{t_f}\, v_x(t)\,dt.
The corresponding ideas of area under the curve when the curve is above the abscissa and over the curve if below the abscissa is illustrated in Fig. .
The area under the curve to get \Delta v_x from a_x versus t plot. The area for the curve when a_x \gt 0 is positive, as between t=0 and t= 2\text{ sec} and the area for the curve when a_x \lt 0 is negative, as between t= 2\text{ sec} and t= 4\text{ sec}.

example.title: Compute \Delta v_x from a_x versus t plot

statement.p: A ball is initially ( t=0 ) moving at v_x = 3\text{ m/s}. The acceleration of the ball at different times are as shown in the a_x versus t plot in . Find v_x at (a) t = 1\text{ sec} , (b) t = 2\text{ sec} , and (c) t = 4\text{ sec} .

solution.title: a
solution.p:
From the area-under-curve we can find the change in v_x during t= 0 to t = 1\text{ sec}. Adding this change to the v_x at t= 0 will give us the v_x at t=1\text{ sec}.
\Delta v_x = \dfrac{1}{2}\times 4 \times 1 = 2\text{ m/s}.
Therefore, v_x at t=1\text{ sec}:
v_x(\text{ at }t=1\text{ sec }) = v_x(\text{ at }t=0\ ) + \Delta v_x = 5\text{ m/s}.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
The area-under-the-curve during t= 1\text{ sec} to t = 2\text{ sec} is zero. Hence the velocity does not change over this interval, i.e., \Delta v_x = 0 .
v_x(\text{ at }t=2\text{ sec }) = v_x(\text{ at }t=1\text{ sec } ) + \Delta v_x = 5\text{ m/s}.

solution.title: c
solution.p:
From the area-under-curve we can find the change in t= 2\text{ sec} to t = 4\text{ sec}. Adding this change to the v_x at t= 2\text{ sec} will give us the v_x at t=4\text{ sec}.
\Delta v_x = -2 \times (4-2) = -4\text{ m/s}.
Therefore, v_x at t=4\text{ sec}:
v_x(\text{ at }t=4\text{ sec }) = v_x(\text{ at }t=2\text{ sec } ) + \Delta v_x = 1\text{ m/s}.
